Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
Comments_List: I learned so much about historic works, but received them in a new way. My writing improved tremendously!
This class covered a wide array of readings and forced me to think critical about the way people engage in arguments and discussion.
I learned about the trial as an idea, as well as historical and literary manifestations of it.
Discussions were riveting. I have no improvements. Challenging but worthwhile experience!

Strengths: fabulous class discussions and often interesting readings
Weaknesses: sometimes the readings felt distant from the topic of the course/discussion.
The strengths are the syllabus, the professor's interesting thoughts and experiences, and the class discussion
The readings were so good!! I could not tell how they related to each other at all at the start of the course, but they definitely tied together at the end.

This course is excellent. The readings are all well-chosen and are extremely diverse in terms of style and time period. Sometimes discussions meandered a little bit, but every class was an engaging experience.
The strengths of the course are its reading list and its professor. The weaknesses are the sheer amount of reading, which is at times unrealistic. This makes it hard to engage fully with the class.
Yes. It can be intimidating but you will grow more comfortable.
Yes, if you are looking for a fun and engaging humanities seminar.
Yes. Professor Thompson is an amazing professor who leads a great seminar. I would recommend this class to anyone.
Yes -- this was an excellent class. The syllabus seemed very varied at first, but everything fit together really well.
YES! The concept of the class is fascinating and the amount of reading/writing really ensures that you are internalizing the material.

I would highly recommend this course to everyone. I grew as a writer and as a thinker through working with Professor Thompson. The demanding syllabus may have made it difficult to actually do all of the required reading, but nonetheless I felt as though I was able to learn quite a bit.
